description: Number of ways to represent 2n+1 as a+b with 0 < a < b and a^2 + b^2 prime.
comments: Zhang Ming-Zhi (zamiz(AT)mail.sc.cninfo.net) asks if a(m) is always >0.I have confirmed that a(n) > 0 for 0 < n < 10^7. - _T. D. Noe_, Oct 17 2004This open problem is mentioned by Guy at the end of section C1. [_T. D. Noe_, Apr 22 2009]a(n) <= phi(2n+1)/2, where phi(m) = A000010(m), while a(n) = phi(2n+1)/2 only for n = 1, 2, and 7. - _Thomas Ordowski_, Jan 25 2014
references: R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems in Theory of Numbers, Section C1.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
mathematica: Table[cnt=0; m=2n+1; Do[If[PrimeQ[k^2+(m-k)^2], cnt++ ], {k, n}]; cnt, {n, 100}]
author: _R. K. Guy_
extensions: More terms from _David W. Wilson_ and _Michael Kleber_
